question: Officer Leland? You know the difference between a black man and nigger? Yeah, most niggers don't. Nice to meet you. So, Winston, what's the difference between a black man and a nigger? Thanks for coming in.
answer: The nigger's the one who falls for your bullshit.

question: Gerald Carver, United States District Attorney. Call me Gerry.
answer: He ought to be wearing a sign.

question: You can tell he's a cop?
answer: He keeps looking for his back-up. Now, the other guy knows it, too.

question: Then why's he taking him to the room?
answer: To rip him off. Too late.

question: Who is he?
answer: Charles Taft. LAPD Narcotics.

question: He's a good cop.
answer: He's a great cop. Two and a . As tough as they come and twice as honest.

question: But the cops aren't getting it done here, are they? Gotta try something new... Who's John Hull?
answer: You are. If you want to be. Most undercover guys don't know what they're doing because it's a day gig. I need somebody who goes under and stays there; six months, a year, five years...

question: What does he have to do?
answer: Buy drugs. Sell drugs. Feed me information.

question: He's a snitch.
answer: He's a drug dealer. A criminal. A scumbag. But for the right side. I want you to come to Los Angeles on loan to the Justice Department as a federal agent. Your experience there will be credited toward your seniority here. And you'll come back to Cleveland a P3 or higher.

question: I can't do that. I've got a wife and kids.
answer: You're separated from your wife, she's filled for divorce. You see your kids every other weekend.

question: All my life I've stayed away from that stuff. I've never touched drugs.
answer: Come on, a little grass...?

question: Not grass. Not nothing. I never even had a drink. Never have, never will. You don't understand. I made a choice in my life.
answer: What's to understand? You saw your father killed when you were ten, and you decided you wouldn't be like that. I'm God, I know everything. You wanted to be a good boy, so you became a cop. Hiding out in uniform... That's why you got the hard-on for Taft.

question: It's not that simple.
answer: I'll tell the truth, Joe. You're never going to be a Taft.

question: I don't believe that.
answer: You ever take a look at your psychological profile? You score almost like a criminal. "Resents authority..."

question: I do not.
answer: "...Exaggerated moral standards, but with no underlying value system." Look at the anger, the repressed violence, it's almost off the scale...

question: Let me see that...
answer: Why'd you join the force?

question: I wanted to be of use.
answer: Well, now you can be. You won't be Taft, but maybe you'll be something more... interesting. There's a man named Ramon Gallegos who supplies 60% of the cocaine to the West Coast. He's smart, smooth, and sufficiently elusive that we don't even have an adult photograph of him. However, his uncle is Hector Guzman, an important Latin American political figure. Gallegos uses Uncle's connections to get product into the country, and everyone we've sent after him has ended up like that...

question: Why would I be different?
answer: You already are, that's the point... You've got the ability and the personality to go underground and blend in completely. That's what the others couldn't. Some part of them showed. That's why they're dead. See, there's only one rule in this game. Don't blow your cover.

question: Joe-J, Carmen... What were you doing with those kids? Your mom lets you play with them? I thought we talked about this. The older brother up there's got a sheet with -- Tito... They're real nice, honey. Is that a horse?
answer: Daddy! It's a bunny... I don't want you to go away, Daddy.

question: It's my work. I've got to. What happened to you there, baby?
answer: Tito did it.

question: He done done, ain't he?
answer: I'm in there.

question: "Where's the Queen," said the King. "She's in bed with laryngitis." "Is that bastard still in town?... Fuck the Queen," said the King, and ten thousand knights straaaained at their utmost... Pina colada times two and a white wine. How you doin', Dudley...
answer: John.

question: John, man, right...
answer: Eddie something... a motormouth... he supplies the street dealers... buys from him... David Elias... who apparently buys from a guy named Barbolla or something. But I haven't seen him.

question: Eddie something... a motormouth... he supplies the street dealers... buys from him... David Elias... who apparently buys from a guy named Barbolla or something. But I haven't seen him.
answer: Barbosa, Felix.

question: There was also a woman, but she's not here. I saw a kid killed. Twelve, thirteen at the most. Turf war.
answer: Get to Elias. Then to Barbosa.

question: You can't rush this stuff.
answer: Rush it, please. I want art, John, not reality. Budget hearings start in April, and I need Gallegos by then. They won't give us funding for three ounce buys.

question: We're not just doing this for the funding, are we?
answer: Without funding, we aren't doing it at all.

question: My man, Dudley, he's so fud-ley...
answer: Eddie, man, I need...

question: So what is it you need so bad, blood? Need, need, need??
answer: A whole K, quick as you can get it.

question: Comin' in the world, Dudley.
answer: All because of my man...

question: Give me a day. Stick around, let the bitch Hoover you, too.
answer: Only if you Clorox him first.

question: Again. Three times four.
answer: Seven.

question: No. You're adding again, you have to multiply. Three and four is seven. Three times four is...
answer: Twelve.

question: Three times five.
answer: Eight.

question: Damn it.
answer: Why can't I just use a calculator?

question: Just a second. Not yet. Let me check on this, first.
answer: Nobody said you had to do the dirty work, David. I'll take care of --

question: Felix, if he's a problem, we'll kill him. I'll kill him myself. Nancy, get out of here.
answer: You got a tasty wife, David. No wonder you don't want us coming here.

question: So what's this, you want to meet me?
answer: I like to know the important customers. You're taking a lot of weight for a guy we hardly know. Where're you moving this stuff, John? We haven't seen you around. We like to have a sense who your customers are.

question: Ah, come on, man, do Macy's tell the Gimbel motherfuckers?
answer: Eddie, forget this guy, he's a cop.

question: Mr. Hull... Mr. Hull...
answer: What's happening, Belinda?

question: Now you know, Mr. Hull, I was to the welfare this afternoon, but the bus, you know what I'm saying?... the one bus, and then the other, and when I got there they'd gone and changed the time on me, without notification. They's supposed to give notification, ain't they? They said I got a thing in the mail, but I don't remember, I don't think they sent it, so now I'm off the welfare, plus I forgot to take James for his shot... for the school? Which otherwise they let him go. And he's gotta learn, he's gotta learn, don't he, Mr. Hull, you tell him, so's he can better hisself.
answer: You had any food today, James? You go to the Mexican place over there, and get the chicken tostada or the beef and bean burrito or both. And a milk. You get the milk! And get something for your mother, too. What do you want?

question: Now, Mr. Hull, if you just --
answer: Two tostadas, two burritos, two milks.

question: You now, I look out for my James best I can, Mr. Hull, but it's hard. Now you like the boy, don't you? I know you do. And I was thinkin' if you wanted to take care of him, that might be good for him. Give him a male figure to look up to.
answer: Look, Belinda, I can't...

question: If you could just give me something for him. Say five thousand dollars... Or maybe four thousand. I couldn't give up my boy for less than four thousand...
answer: It's me. I'm here... Where?... five minutes.

question: running. Police and SIRENS pursuing. He hurls the Fed Ex envelope into a dumpster. HELICOPTER light sweeps over him.
answer: Thank you kindly... How you doin', child?...

question: You...
answer: Me? Of course, it's me. You know me? Hurts, huh? Here, I want to show you something. You have kids? These are mine. Aren't they the most beautiful children you ever saw? Yeah, I know, they kind of leave you speechless. So let me ask, if someone put a gun to your baby's head, wouldn't you kill him if you could? Me, too. And you're the bastard with the gun.

question: You know the difference between a nigger and a black man?
answer: Don't jive me, boy.

question: The nigger's the one covers Whitey's ass by puttin' the brothers in jail.
answer: You ain't my brother.

question: You're a lawyer??
answer: I'm your lawyer.

question: Who hired you?
answer: It's pro bono. If you don't want me, there's Shelley. She's good. She just can't provide special services...

question: Like what?
answer: Getting your case called first. Your Honor, I believe the preliminary police toxicology report will show that the substance seized from my client was Mannitol, a baby laxative. We move for immediate dismissal. We're out of here, Dude.

question: Shut up, you little faggot.
answer: The cops made you give them somebody. We know it.

question: All right, so what? I mean, so what, man? You got the money. Twenty-six G. Twenty-six, David. Count it.
answer: Next time you might trade us.

question: Never. Never, Felix, never. Come on, man, you know I'd never...
answer: I know you never will.

question: Felix, no. Don't be... I'm worth money to you. Let me give you money.
answer: Why? You don't owe me anything.

question: Another twenty-six grand... Just to show you... Fifty.
answer: Why not a hundred?

question: A hundred??? Felix... Okay, a hundred.
answer: Give it.

question: Tomorrow. Twenty-four hours.
answer: Now. Ten seconds.

question: Felix, I need time. I --
answer: One... two...

question: Eddie, man... He was always nice to my daughter.
answer: How'd a guy like you get into this?

question: The way most drug lawyers do
answer: Yeah. And now...?

question: The road gets rougher. Cocaine's a dying business.
answer: Then what are we doing here?

question: People are always going to want to get high. Every society has ways to alter consciousness.
answer: Because they can't bear reality.

question: We all need our delusions, only the means change
answer: What's next? Why aren't you selling it?

question: I know how to make it and market it. But I need capital. That's the only reason I'm hanging out with an asshole like Barbosa. And because I can't get to the big guys.
answer: Who are the big guys?

question: Gallegos, et cetera.
answer: Why can't you get to them?

question: What do you care? Anyway, designer drugs have a bad name
answer: Sounds like a dream.

question: In dreams begin responsibilities.
answer: Tell me about this new shit.

question: That's my friend, John. This is Miranda.
answer: Hi, Miranda.

question: Nancy, this is John. That's not about you. It's, she's... judgmental about what I do.
answer: That's more than I bought.

question: Half we owe you. The other half's on consignment. A token of our esteem.
answer: You're having trouble moving it. Make me your partner. I'll help you get your capital.

question: I can't buy this much shit. I haven't got it in the budget.
answer: What am I supposed to do with it?

question: You're a drug dealer, John. Deal drugs.
answer: You know how this goes, Gerry. It won't stop here. You know what they're going to ask me to do pretty soon, to prove I'm down. What am I supposed to do then?

question: Don't blow your Carver. You're still thinking like a cop, John. Forget that. Cross the line. Be what you are. You're a criminal. You don't give a shit about other people. You're just trying to survive.
answer: I can't do this shit. I just can't.

question: But you want to be of use. You want to get drugs off the street, don't you?
answer: That's why I'm here.

question: Well, this is the cost. Pay it or go grow flowers someplace.
answer: You can't back down with them. You've got to project strength, from inside, you know? Cocksucker... 'Cause I can, motherfucker, 'cause I can. ...Touch her again, motherfuckers, I'm gonna mess you up. Is David Elias here?

question: You can't back down with them. You've got to project strength, from inside, you know? Cocksucker... 'Cause I can, motherfucker, 'cause I can. ...Touch her again, motherfuckers, I'm gonna mess you up. Is David Elias here?
answer: Momentito... Jacqueline, ho-ney... "Who's making love to your old lady... while you're out make love...?" How come I like balling black chicks so much?

question: 'Cause you're a racist asshole. You feel like you're fucking a slave, and it gets you off.
answer: Oh, don't mau mau me with the Malcolm X shit. Tell me you're not chasin' white pussy every chance you get.

question: I don't dig white women. Even if I did, it wouldn't mean the same thing.
answer: Sure, it'd be the slave fucking the master. Hegel talks about it. Just like me, but the other way around.

question: Fuck Hegel. Who the fuck is Hegel? Some smart-ass kike that talks backwards?
answer: Everybody digs the other, John. They dig their own, and they dig the other.

question: Does your wife dig black guys, David? Did she fuck Eddie? Does she want to fuck me?
answer: Ooo... you mean with that great big purple dick of yours? I hope not. She'd never be impressed with my little thing again.

question: You think what impresses her now is your dick?
answer: What does impress her? Betty, this is John, my new associate.

question: Come on, Eddie 2... you're up.
answer: No, thanks.

question: Who is he, my mother?
answer: Never have, never will.

question: John's an ascetic Negro; he wants to make sure you know he's not a jungle bunny.
answer: Watch your mouth, David.

question: But he's got another side. You should seen him on the street the other day with these two USC kids. Do the spade bit for her, John. I'm gonna mess you up, muthafugga...
answer: Don't call me a spade. And don't tell me to play black.

question: Come on, John, you do it so well. Ah ain't playin', muthafucka. Ah ain't playin'. Don't fuckin' dis me, muthafucka. Fucka... fucka... fucka a... fucka b... fuck b-hive... fucka, fucka, fucka...
answer: Say it again, and I'll kill you.

question: You gotta pay anyway. Shit... Bijoux!!
answer: It wasn't your fault. What could you have done?

question: She worked for me. I'm supposed to protect her.
answer: We have to kill him. Or we lose all authority with the other dealers. And one of them'll kill you. You've got to assert now, or you're dead. And if we kill Ivy, we control this whole territory.

question: That guy who works for Barbosa can do it, Chino.
answer: No. If we use Chino, it's Barbosa who's asserting. It'll be Barbosa's territory. It's gotta be us.

question: Right.
answer: And if it's us, it's gotta be you.

question: Don't blow your cover.
answer: What?

question: If I do this, we're partners. Equal partners on everything. Let's go.
answer: Now...?

question: Go wait around back.
answer: I want to see you in that alley.

question: ...Carmen, it's me. It's Daddy...
answer: Daddy!!

question: Hi, baby. How are you? I miss you!
answer: What?

question: I miss you...
answer: I miss you, too, Daddy...

question: Nobel prizes are for wussies.
answer: What does this shit do to you?

question: I'm on it now. It's like cocaine only better. Want some?
answer: I don't take drugs.

question: Synthetic shit?? Sounds like a 20/20 segment... So, what was it like?
answer: What was what like?

question: Popping Ivy...
answer: You knew.

question: I'm God, remember?
answer: Then you should know how it was.

question: You didn't clear it with me. You're getting independent. That's good. How're we coming on Gallegos?
answer: He supplies Barbosa. To get to him we'll have to take quantity.

question: Then you've got to --
answer: That's what killing Ivy did. I'll get to him soon. Is that it?

question: I want you to get a new apartment. Something expensive.
answer: I like where I am.

question: That shithole? You're big time now. Act it. And get some clothes. Spend money. Have fun. That's an order.
answer: Whether I'm here or not, no one else uses that room. And change the linen twice a week, just like now. And make sure James gets what he needs. And something for you.

question: Whether I'm here or not, no one else uses that room. And change the linen twice a week, just like now. And make sure James gets what he needs. And something for you.
answer: Nice place. Nice suit.

question: Hey...!
answer: You pick all this shit out yourself?

question: A Jewish lady in the store helped me.
answer: Aw... Very nice. Understated. I'm impressed.

question: Fifty bucks, fifty fucking bucks...
answer: You sold it all? I'll order a couple more keys from Barbosa.

question: Order ten.
answer: Ten??

question: Better twenty.
answer: I don't want to push it.

question: I do. We've got a bigger territory, we need more product. I want to deal directly with Gallegos. It would save us money.
answer: Barbosa'll never let us near him.

question: If we buy twenty, Gallegos'll come to us himself.
answer: How do you know?

question: When I bought a key from Eddie, you came to me. Who's above Gallegos?
answer: Guzman, but he's... Don't ask so many questions.

question: How else will I learn? Call Barbosa, David, put in our order... Because we have to split this, and there isn't enough here for both of us.
answer: Look, I'm tired, why don't you... Why do you look at me like that?

question: How do I look at you?
answer: Like you know something I don't. Like you're better than me.

question: I don't think I'm better than you. I don't think I'm better than anybody. But I do know something... You can't stop thinking about me.
answer: Let's go back here... Do this... do it with me. This is where I'm at. You want to be with me, it's gotta be there.

question: I don't do that.
answer: Never have, never will.

question: It's for fuck-ups.
answer: What do you think, you're not a nigger? You're a nigger as much as me.

question: I'm not talking to you at all. I'm talking to John.
answer: It's the cocaine. Don't listen to him. Felix, you've had enough...

question: Shmuck.
answer: Praise God they don't let guns in here.

question: David, you've been working out, you're getting strong. Are you quick, too? Come on, I'll give you a shot at me.
answer: Any time, any place.

question: Right here, right now. Do this.
answer: This? What is this?

question: They're already wondering.
answer: You can have Gopher.

question: Oh Gawd...
answer: How about a lawyer?

question: Great, lawyers are great, Jewish is best. But I need spades, too. The politicians want dark facts to scare the suburbs so they'll vote Republican.
answer: Lawyers and spades; I got the trifecta

question: You're my man. And afterwards...
answer: When this is over, I'll send you to Hawaii, Maui. It's very beautiful in Maui, it's a very spiritual place.

question: We're getting twenty kilograms tomorrow. Tonight. I made it happen. I pushed Elias, now he doesn't make a move without me.
answer: You run Elias.

question: I control him. Barbosa's selling it to us because he thinks I can move it... And last night I met Ramon Gallegos. We're getting the dope from him; it's still coming through Barbosa, but Gallegos will approach me soon on his own. We're going to get him, Gerry. We're going to bring him and the whole thing down. What's your problem?
answer: My problem? My problem is that you don't really know what's happening.

question: Oh, so, tell me what's happening, Gerry.
answer: Barbosa is setting you up tonight.

question: Bullshit.
answer: He's dealing you to Taft and Hernandez. You're going to be taken down as you receive the drugs. They're putting together the arrest team right now.

question: What do we do?
answer: You stay away. We're going to take them down.

question: Who? Elias and Betty? Don't be silly.
answer: My boss wants a bust right now. He goes before the oversight committee next week. He needs something to justify the budget.

question: I'll get him something. Give me ten days, and I'll get him Gallegos on a plate.
answer: Too late. The whole thing's set up.

question: Gerry, what are you telling me? I need Elias... and Betty. You arrest them, and you're throwing away everything I've set up.
answer: It's out of my hands. John, don't go near that bust.

question: watching planes descend into the airport, nervous. He knows what's coming, but how does he handle it? Let's see what we've got. Don't touch it.
answer: What is this?

question: Something's wrong. What's that van doing there? This is a bust. The minute we take the stuff, they'll be over us.
answer: He's crazy, David. I thought you were the crazy one, but it's him.

question: Chino, pick up the suitcase and give it to Elias. I'll only kill him if something goes wrong.
answer: No!!

question: Everything is different. We're the Colombians now. This is the greatest night of my life. Terrible but great. Felix was right...
answer: About what?

question: He said I should kill a man. He was right.
answer: My God.

question: Barbosa was a roach. Do you miss him? Will anybody in the world miss him?
answer: Are you a roach, too?

question: Yes. Thank God.
answer: What about you? Stop the car. Stop it! No more laundering, no more anything. I'm finished with this.

question: She knows too much. We have to kill her.
answer: No! She's with me. She's not going to talk. You touch her, I'll kill you.

question: She's your responsibility then. We're going to get the money now, John. Enough for the new drug. We're going to be rich. We're going to be so rich that we're going to leave the world of ordinary people and going to a higher realm. I mean that.
answer: They're going to come after us.

question: Where the hell is all the money? We're still a million short.
answer: I gotta get laid.

question: David, we've got thirty-six hours.
answer: Pick me up at Jacqueline's in the morning.

question: Sooner than that.
answer: Get in.

question: What are you doing here? You're going to get me killed.
answer: Where the hell have you been?

question: Doing my job.
answer: You violated a direct order to stay away from that bust. As a result, a police informant is dead, a state senator was critically injured in the tunnel pile up and a city policeman was subsequently murdered.

question: I didn't blow my cover.
answer: Don't get smart with me, motherfucker.

question: Don't be a shmuck, Gerry. I'm talking to Gallegos. I'm collecting his money. We can set him up right now.
answer: Never have, never will. I want you to give me your gun. You're coming in right now.

question: Coming in where?
answer: Your assignment has been terminated. You're not going out there again. If I have to, I'll put you in custody.

question: I'm going to have Gallegos in two days. You're protecting him. You're protecting Gallegos. No, of course. That's why you wanted to bust Elias and Betty. I was getting close, and you wanted to cut this off then... What is he, the new Noriega? Helps you fight commies, so you let him sell drugs to the niggers. Two birds with one stone.
answer: You violated orders, so you're through. Don't make a conspiracy theory out of it.

question: I'm through...? Then, I might as well have a drink after all. Now tell me the truth or they're going to decide your troubles got the best of you.
answer: You're insane.

question: All the more reason to do what I say. Jesus, Ger, I'm having trouble holding on...
answer: All right!

question: Say it!
answer: It's the State Department. I told you, Gallegos's uncle is a big deal down there.

question: Guzman.
answer: Guzman, right. Our government supports Guzman because he's a moderate. That's a right-winger who's pro-U.S. If Gallegos got busted here, it would hurt Guzman's political career there. It's politics, John, not drugs.

question: Drugs is politics. Politics is drugs... Christ, Gerry, I dealt drugs. I killed a man. Others died. What did I do all this for? For nothing.
answer: I'm going to Washington, John. I'll bring you with me. We'll have clout, money...

question: I didn't do this for clout or money. You said we were gonna do some good.
answer: We tried.

question: Trying's for college boys. If all there is is power and money... If all there is... then what am I doing here? 'Cause I can get more power and money out on the street, I got more there already, than I'd ever get kissing your ass in Washington...
answer: But you can't do that, John. It's not you.

question: Me? There is no me. We took care of that. First I was a cop pretending to be a dealer. Now I'm just a dealer pretending to be a cop. Why not stop pretending...? Quit the force. Be a dealer.
answer: It's not that simple.

question: My assignment's already terminated. All I have to do is quit. I hereby quit. My first one. Not so bad.
answer: Don't blow your cover.

question: What's the matter?
answer: Who are you, my mother?

question: Tell me.
answer: Tell you what?

question: What you came to say.
answer: What did I come to say?

question: Then tell me anything. Something about you. Something real.
answer: When I was young, I occasionally stole things. My father died when I was ten. Right in front of me. Heart attack. He just fell down. He said, "I love you," then died in my arms.

question: Oh, baby... Tell me what's going on, John?
answer: You're not doing the stuff anymore, are you?

question: No. Don't change the subject.
answer: How is that?

question: It's hard. John...!
answer: Things are getting, they're getting a little... confusing. I had certain plans, and people haven't come through exactly as they promised.

question: What do you expect with those people?
answer: It's not just those people. It's... it's bigger than that. It's of everybody. Present company excluded.

question: You've got to stop this, John, you know that. You gotta get out.
answer: I can't.

question: Of course, you can.
answer: No! This is what I'm supposed to do.

question: Supposed to? Who said you're supposed to?
answer: The whole fuckin' world. You think I didn't try something else? But everything funnels you right back here. Like it's where you had to go all along.

question: But you know what you're doing, don't you, selling this stuff? Doing to our own.
answer: If I tried to get out now, they'd kill me.

question: I can't be with somebody's who involved in drugs.
answer: Everyone knows what he is There've got to be more. We have a million two, we owe Gallegos one eight.

question: I got every money transfer, every phone call, all your laundry tickets.
answer: What do you want?

question: John Hull.
answer: I can't!

question: Big brass balls. Collecting money makes you strong.
answer: What's that?

question: I'm telling our suppliers they got paid. They'll be very happy. I'm happy.
answer: And we're happy. Everybody's happy. It's a happy world.

question: So, how can I express my gratitude for a job well done?
answer: We want Barbosa's business.

question: Done. Of course.
answer: And, also, your business. All this. Your money, your dope, everything.

question: You're tougher than I thought, but not that tough.
answer: How tough is enough?

question: How tough is enough?
answer: No!

question: Thank you, John. I couldn't have done that without you.
answer: Jesus Christ...

question: You taught me to take my work seriously.
answer: What's going on here, David?

question: We're taking over.
answer: You're doing too much stuff.

question: No, I'm very clear. I'm very, very clear. Ahora, usted nos assistamos. Enteindo? Donde esta?
answer: What the fuck's the matter with you?

question: It works, John. It works.
answer: Jesus...

question: Disce a Senor Guzman que... ...that we have his money, and we're willing to talk as soon as he comes to town. We'll know how to reach him. Okay? Approximating the cubic capacity and depending on the denominations of the bills, it's somewhere between fifty million and two hundred million dollars. Right back there. Think I'm crazy?
answer: Yes. I can't believe you got us into this. All of fucking Latin America is going to be after our asses, including Renaldo Guzman who's friends with fucking George Bush.

question: I know they're coming after us. I want them to. We'll give them the money, but we'll make a deal for ourselves. We'll get what we need for the synthetic drugs. I've thought it all out. I've been thinking it out for years. We're going to have everything. Don't you want everything, John?
answer: They're going to get your family, David. They'll kill your wife and daughter.

question: Nancy and Miranda left the country two days ago.
answer: You knew about this then? What about Betty?

question: Cute kids...
answer: Give me that.

question: Tell me something, who the fuck are you? 'Cause I don't think you're quite the asshole you're trying to be.
answer: Look, Mr. Taft, that's your name, right? Leave me alone. I got things on my mind.

question: I'd think you would. You better have your goddamn life on your mind, or it's gonna get away from you. It's gonna burn up like that poor woman across the way. Like all of you's gonna burn...
answer: And what do you do, Mr. Taft, except chase bad guys up and down the street with your dirty partner, never catching anybody important?

question: I do what I can. Do you do what you can? Maybe my partner was dirty. Maybe the chief's dirty. And the mayor. And the President. Maybe God Himself's taking something on the side. That's their problem. But I'll bust 'em if I can.
answer: Get out of my room.

question: Don't deny who you are.
answer: They're my children. They live in Cleveland with their mother. I'm divorced from her. I haven't seen them in... some time. I want to, but I haven't been able to arrange it.

question: They're my children. They live in Cleveland with their mother. I'm divorced from her. I haven't seen them in... some time. I want to, but I haven't been able to arrange it.
answer: How much else don't I know about you?

question: Everything else... Everything else is... I don't know.
answer: Taft has all the evidence about my laundering. He's going to put me in jail for a long time unless I give you up.

question: Do it.
answer: I can't. So, I've got to get away. Far away. But I need money.

question: Money? I got money... International terminal. I'll meet you there in a week.
answer: You know the first time, when I saw you in the bar...?

question: You wouldn't even look at me.
answer: 'Cause I knew what you were thinking. You were judging me.

question: No, I wasn't, I was...
answer: You were. Your eyes were like an angel in my heart telling me I should be good, and I didn't want to hear it. That's you, too. Maybe this is you, I don't know, but I know that's you.

question: Yes... Where?... No! No way... We pick the time and place... Otherwise no meet... Got a pencil? We have a proposal to make. We regret what happened to your nephew...
answer: Say what you have to say.

question: We all know that your cousin's business is coming to an end. Costs have climbed while profits and the market -- We have developed a new product
answer: The racist Americans just want to cut us poor Hispanics out of the market.

question: We did it. Twenty million. Twenty fucking million. We're going to have synthetics. We're gonna be rich. We're gonna... What's the matter, John? Be happy. Your whole life has just been solved. John, where are you going?
answer: Oh, Jesus, no...

question: John, what the hell are you doing? Let's get out of here.
answer: He's dying.

question: Let him die. Let him die twice. Come one.
answer: Get help.

question: Yeah, I'm a cop. I'm a fucking cop...
answer: Oh, really? Where's you badge?

question: I don't have one. I'm undercover. Get help, David.
answer: John, that's a cop. He tried to kill you.

question: He didn't know.
answer: Oh, he didn't know. I don't know. Maybe you don't know. Maybe you think you're a cop because... because...

question: Drop the gun, put your hands against the car. Spread your legs... Police! My God! Please...
answer: Okay, let's say you're a cop. Be a cop. We've still got the money. We put it into Randy's chemistry set. In five years we're worth five hundred million each, minimum. You'll be one of the richest black men in America. Richer than Cosby. Who gives a shit how you got it? You think the white ones were honest? Is this asshole all that stands between you and greatness? Let me do you a favor. Gee, John, that's kind of an extreme reaction.

question: What about Guzman?
answer: He vanished, thank God, or we'd both be in deep doo-doo. At least you got Gallegos.

question: Elias did. And everything goes on as before.
answer: That's the drug game. Plus a change... I want you to come back to work for me. You'll beat all charges on a technicality and go back to who you were.

question: Who was I, Ger?
answer: Does anyone really know?

question: I have other things to do.
answer: Like travel? Tangiers, maybe? I'm God, remember? Go back to work, she walks out of here. Otherwise, she's up on multiple counts, and I'll see to it the judge runs them consecutively.
